title: Designing Cooling Corridors in Expanding Cities

paragraphs.text: Urban planners in rapidly growing subtropical cities are experimenting with cooling corridors—linked parks and shaded streets that guide prevailing winds into overheated districts. Inspired by traditional hutong layouts in Beijing, these corridors prioritize narrow passages that funnel breezes while blocking glare. Remote sensing teams map the hottest surfaces each summer so landscape architects can plant drought-tolerant trees along the precise routes that transport relief.
paragraphs.summary: 规划师仿照胡同布局建造‘清凉走廊’，利用风向和耐旱树木为酷热街区降温。

paragraphs.text: Yet the projects can falter when maintenance budgets remain tied to short election cycles. Newly planted trees require three years of irrigation before their canopies deliver noticeable shade, but councillors often redirect funding after the first season because voters expect instant cooling. Community cooperatives in Guangzhou address this gap by collecting water from rooftop cisterns and scheduling weekend mulching brigades, ensuring the saplings survive beyond the political calendar.
paragraphs.summary: 资金断档常导致项目失败，但广州社区合作社通过自筹灌溉和义工维护来弥补。

paragraphs.text: As corridors mature, data from wearable sensors show that residents who commute along the shaded routes experience lower heart rates during heat waves. Hospitals report fewer dehydration admissions from neighborhoods adjacent to the connected greenways, particularly among elderly residents. These early health outcomes convince skeptical policymakers that investment in patient, community-led maintenance produces measurable public-health dividends.
paragraphs.summary: 成熟的走廊降低通勤者心率，减少脱水病例，证明持续投入能带来健康回报。

questions.prompt: According to paragraph 1, why do planners study traditional hutong street patterns?
options: To maximize the amount of direct sunlight hitting new developments.
To harness narrow pathways that can steer wind through hot districts.
To copy the exact architectural aesthetics of historic neighborhoods.
To create tourist routes that highlight cultural heritage sites.
questions.answer: To harness narrow pathways that can steer wind through hot districts.
questions.explanation: 段落指出胡同布局被用来引导风穿过高温区域。

distractors.choice: To maximize the amount of direct sunlight hitting new developments.
distractors.analysis: 原文强调阻挡眩光、降低热度，而不是增加日照。

distractors.choice: To copy the exact architectural aesthetics of historic neighborhoods.
distractors.analysis: 段落关注功能性降温，而非美学复刻。

distractors.choice: To create tourist routes that highlight cultural heritage sites.
distractors.analysis: 文本未提及旅游或文化观光目的。
